title: 109_s2199
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting America's Competitive Edge Through Tax Incentives Act of 2006" or the "PACE-Finance Act." It includes an expansion of the credit for research and development. The "Protecting America's Competitive Edge Through Tax Incentives Act of 2006" expands the credit for research and development by making the credit permanent, doubling the credit rate to 40 percent, and authorizing new regulations for tax audits. The "Protecting America's Competitive Edge Through Tax Incentives Act of 2006" expands the research and development tax credit to reflect technological advancements and collaborative research consortia. The Act expands the research and development tax credit by studying methods to broaden the scope of the credit under section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes modifying the credit to remove the incremental approach and expanding qualifying research and development expenditures. Expansion of research and development tax credit to include certain employee benefit costs, contract research costs, all expenditures qualifying under section 174 of the Code, and other costs deemed appropriate by the Secretary. Reduction or elimination of credit limitation under section 280C(c) of the Code. Effective date for amendments is taxable years beginning after December 31, 2005. The United States-based innovation incentives study is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of the Treasury will analyze the US tax system's impact on innovation investment, comparing it to other nations. The analysis will cover capital gains treatment, corporate tax rate, and incentives for high-tech manufacturing. A report is due within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury will report on the analysis of the US tax system's impact on innovation investment to the President and relevant congressional committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. EMPLOYEE CONTINUING EDUCATION TAX CREDIT. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section for an Employee Continuing Education Credit. The Employee Continuing Education Credit allows employers to claim a credit for qualified continuing education costs paid for science or engineering education of employees, limited to $500,000,000 per calendar year. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for employee continuing education credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, limited to $500,000,000 per year. The Code of 1986 is amended to disallow deductions for expenses equal to the employee continuing education credit determined under section 45N(a). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to costs paid or incurred in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2005.
